text:
- Welcome to the Executive
Insights podcast,
brought to you by AWS.
My name is Becky Weiss.

I'm a vice president and
distinguished engineer at AWS,

and I am thrilled to be here
talking today to Tony Chor.
Tony is a VP at Amazon,
and he runs our BuilderWorks organization.

So Tony, can you tell us a
little bit about what that is?
- Yeah, sure thing.

Thanks for having me.
- Of course.

- I lead a development
team that designs, builds,

and operates the systems that
other Amazon builders use
to create the shopping experiences

that hopefully most of our
listeners are familiar with.
This is everything from our homepage
and our mobile shopping applications,
all the way through to manage,
compute data, networking systems,
all built on top of AWS, of course.

And I've been doing this I
think about 11 years now.

- Fantastic. Thank you
so much for joining us.

So what we are here to talk
about today, our topic for today

is developer use of generative
AI in organizations.
This is a very hot topic out in the world.
Because it has a lot of

technical and non-technical
aspects, right?

There's an incredible potential
for improved productivity,
incredible potential for improved quality.

And at the same time,
it is definitely a shift
in how we engineers do our jobs,

and there's a little bit of
both excitement and anxiety
surrounding that change.

And so, we're going to
talk a little bit about
how you are managing that change
in your organization,
how you address developers' concerns, and

what your developers are
already getting out of it.

You run a very large
development organization.

Tell us a little bit about
some wins, some success stories

of use of generative
AI by your developers.
- Sure, I mean, we're a really traditional

backend Java services team
primarily, not a science team.
And so we've been...

I think like a lot of
teams, a lot of companies,
just on this learning journey

through the new tools and
the changes that are there.
So, we're taking some of the tools

from AWS, first, CodeWhisperer,
and now, Q Code Dev.
We've been working with that,

and some teams have found
it really helpful for them.

In other cases, we've had
to wait for a few months

to get a new update to
see the improvements,

and we've also learned that we
have to train our developers
to use new tools too.

They don't just work out
of the box necessarily.
They have to shift their mindset.

But in other places,
we've started using gen AI

to answer questions for
our internal support.
We're just now getting to the point
where the accuracy is good enough

and the teams are finding
it super helpful for that.

And as we're bootstrapping
ourselves up into this now
and using the tools more
and the technologies that are available,
the teams are starting to think
about the problems differently,
which is really exciting to see.
And so, they're starting to become
non-obvious uses for the tools.

It turns out the LLMs
really can understand
code pretty well,

and then translate that
into useful insights.
So maybe a small thing we've done

that's been really paying off
now is in our build pipelines,

we automatically generate
the release notes
after every build.
No developer likes to write release notes.
They often don't do a good job of it,

but the LLM goes through,
looks at all the changes,
and summarizes for them.

The developer okays it,
and we publish that out,
so the quality of our documentation
has gotten much better.

And actually, we're seeing
a lot, maybe the most wins
on this sort of outer loop stuff,
not the inner loop of coding and-
- Yeah, because actually the fact is,

we spend a very small...
- [Tony] Very small amount of time.
- ... percentage of our time on this.

- Right, right, it's the
answering questions, summarizing,
writing documentation, things like that,

which the developers aren't
great at, don't all love doing.

And it's really where we
spend a lot of the time,

and that's, to me, been
the biggest surprise is
where we're seeing those wins.
- Yeah, I mean, Tony, this is something
that I've experienced myself is

that one of the greatest
quality opportunities

for use of generative
AI is in all of those,

you call them outer loop,
all of those outer loop tasks

that most developers
actually don't want to do.

It's not what they were
excited about doing.

And more so when they're
crunched for time,

they have a boss
breathing down their neck,
the things, the deadline's next week,
it's going to be the first thing
that they start to skimp on.
And these are tasks where,

these are tasks where I
think we're already seeing
that Q Developer has a real sweet spot.
And you talk about release notes.

You know that actually
most of the toil there
actually isn't even the unit testing.
It's building all of the scaffolding

to create the conditions
that you need to test.
That stuff just...
That stuff isn't rocket science,
but it requires activation energy,
time, time spent debugging,
and it really does shorten that time
so that I have more time to do the parts
that I actually was interested in,
that I actually wanted to do.
As you talk to your engineers though,

my guess is you probably
hear a mixed bag...

- Oh, for sure.
- ... of reactions to this change.
- Yeah, yeah, for sure. Absolutely.
I think like any new thing,

there's some population
that's really eager
to embrace it and curious.

There's a whole bunch
of sort of undecided,

and then there's a bunch
of sort of skeptics,

frankly, all the way to people
who are afraid of change.
I mean, there's no change without loss
or perceived loss anyway.
Maybe one of the biggest surprises for us
as we started embarking on this journey is

that the group that is
embracing the change the most

and is really driving and
leading a lot of our efforts
are some of our more junior engineers.
The ones right out of college
that don't have set ways of working
or maybe have been exposed

to some of these technologies
in college and stuff,

and they're the ones teaching
our principal engineers

which as you know, for most
of our traditional systems,
that's not the case.

Normally, it's often our
sort of senior leaders
guiding and setting direction and stuff.

And here, it's much more of
everybody's learning together,
and sometimes it's the junior engineers
who are really teaching the most.
And what we're seeing now is,

as we get past the initial
wave of the hype cycle,

people are seeing the reality
of what the tools can do,

that sort of skeptical group
is starting to be won over.
- Right.

- Now, they're seeing,
"Wow, this really is...
It can do something useful here."
It is maybe not what the hype said,
but it's super valuable, super useful

in a really radically different
way of working and thinking.

So people who've been
working in the same space
for 10 years or something are now,
suddenly showing to work
with a bounce in their step,

and they're really excited
to try these new approaches.
- There's a lot of hype around gen AI,
and particularly gen AI writing code.

If you read the hype, you
might go into it expecting,
well, wow, this is...
This is going to do everything.
This is going to make me breakfast.

- Right, right.
- Right?

And if you go in with that
expectation, you will find
that it did not make you breakfast.
And if you go in with those expectations,
you'll be disappointed.

And then the question is,
what do you do from there?

If you're an experienced
technologist, you know that,

"Okay, the thing I tried
wasn't the sweet spot.
I need to actually look for...

I need to look for where this
match and where this fit is."
You need to keep probing for that.

I can also imagine a reaction
like, "No breakfast."
So that's one way of looking at this.

The other way is sort
of what you talked about
with the junior engineers,

and I'm going to go
even farther than that.

I've talked to customers who
have put forth the hypothesis,
that I think may well be correct,
that the next wave of what we think
of as "technological innovations"
may not actually come from the people
we think of as technologists anymore.

- I think that's right.
- Yeah.
And so, it's a very different audience.
It's going to be consuming this,
who's going to be making things with this.
I'm very, very eager to see
what that looks like, because I myself am
an experienced technologist,

and so I know how my
side of the world works,
and, of course, how we deal with,
with expectations of a new technology,
and then dashed expectations,
and then figuring out the sweet spot.

I'm very curious to
see how this other side
is going to play out.
- Yeah, I think that's right.

I mean, the history of our
industry really is democratizing
what was constrained to a set of experts
and allowing a lot more people
to be able to take advantage of.

Word processing even is
a good example of that.
But digital photography, digital music
have really opened up the audience

that can express themselves
and can build things now.

And I absolutely believe
that gen AI will do that,
more outside of the traditional realm

of what we would consider as
developers or builders today.
- Yeah.
Now, of course, there's a little bit
of an elephant in the room on that one.

The dual of lots of
people can do my job now
is a fear of job displacement.
Have you heard that from your staff?
- Yeah, of course. Of course.
I think, again,

we've been through many
waves like this together,
and there's always that kind of concern.
I think some of it's real.

Though, if you define your job
as the things you do today,

then I think there will
be some displacement.
But if you think of your job
as problem-solving and building and stuff,
the content of your work,

a lot of people's work
will change our work.
The content of our work will change.
- For sure.
- But the roles will still be there.
There'll still be a need for people
who can think, dream, invent,

and listen to customers
and address those concerns
to operate big systems and things,
and we'll just do it differently.
- Yeah, I do actually think

that there's a possible very
good outcome from all of this,

which is that the human side
of what we bring to work
is actually going to be maximized.
I'll give you an example.
It's actually not about code,
it's about another use of gen AI

that I'm very enthusiastic
about, which is summarizing.
- Yes.

- So Amazon is famous
for its document culture.

We communicate with
each other in documents.
Of course, that means a lot of reading
if you're on the receiving end of that.

And as a senior engineer
in the organization

who interfaces with a lot
of different parts of AWS
and deals with a fairly large cast
of characters in any given day,
I often get a Slack message from someone

that says, "Hey, Becky, you
might find this interesting."

Document link.
- Right.
- Right? What do you do with that?
Before I had these tools at my disposal,

I had to just triage
aggressively based on criteria

that may have been good
and may not have been good.

Do I know this person?
What do I think they work on?

What do I think this
document's going to say?

And I would choose whether
to go look at it or not.
And I know because I now get the chance
to summarize these documents,

it quickly makes me a much
more responsive colleague.
I can respond to them in 30 seconds.

Whereas before, I would
need to have even decided

that I'm going to open
the link and take a look.
- And I think on that same summary note,
one of the things I've loved the most now,
and you're familiar with this too,

is in our ticketing system,
as a leader of these systems,
I am jumping in and out all day,
and it was always hard to know

what's the current status
of the event and stuff.
And now, I can look at this great summary.

Frankly, it's better than
the human-generated ones

in most cases.
- [Becky] Oh, for sure.

- And I can start doing the
human part of it, like you said,
thinking, analyzing, prioritizing,
instead of having to spend my time
pouring through the ticket

and trying to figure out
what the status is and stuff.
It's been a real dream, frankly.
- Yeah, I can relate to that as well.

At AWS, our developers
are, for the most part,
extremely hands-on, operationally involved

in the availability, in
resilience, of our services.
One of my jobs at AWS is a call leader,
which means that, in the rare event
we have an operational issue,
of course we do what you think.

You have a conference
call with lots of people,
professionally moderated and led.
And you get paged into one of these calls,
the ticket's on fire.
People are saying all kinds of stuff,

and they've been saying all
kinds of stuff for a while,

and the stuff towards
the bottom of the ticket
is actually not that accurate anymore.

That's what they think was
happening until they learn more.
And these summaries are so good,

because before that, I was
trying to read the ticket

and assess which parts of it
are useful and not useful,

all the while people are
talking to me, and...

- That's right.
- Right.
And it's just, it allows me to apply
the human part of this call leader role,

because I'm no longer
just spending my time

buried in a ticket
trying to understand it.
- Yeah, that's right. That's right.
- And all of this is outer loop stuff.
All of this is outer loop stuff.

You're looking at code somebody
wrote 5 years, 10 years ago.
And I'm an experienced engineer.

I know I have methods
for tracing it through,
walking it through.
I know how to read code.

It is much nicer to be
able to ask something like,

"Break this down for
me. What does this do?

How is it structured?"
- Yeah, that's right.
That's right.

- And It doesn't actually
atrophy my skills in any way.
It just shortens the part

that I was sort of doing
mechanically before.
- Yeah, that makes a ton of sense.

So, how do you think then,
for you and for the developers

and maybe more junior
developers you're working with,
how is this going to change career growth

and the kinds of things
people will have to learn?
What will be different?

- Well, I don't actually
think this is a new thing
in our industry.
The technology itself is certainly new,
but technological shifts are not that new.
10 years ago, early in my career at AWS,
I used to work on virtual private cloud.
This is the networking,
this is the network capabilities of EC2,

meaning customers have
control over many aspects
of their network, network security,
network logging, all of these things.

And this was much earlier
in cloud adoption,
back in 2013, '14.
Certainly, customers you've heard of
were adopting the cloud,

but a lot hadn't set
foot in the cloud yet.
So, you were talking to a lot of customers

at the beginning of their
cloud migration journey,

and one of the characters
you would talk to

are the folks who would
manage the data center network

for the customers before
they come into AWS.

So you're talking to them
about virtual private cloud
and about what they can do with this.
They get this unprecedented visibility
and control, and it's all API driven,
meaning that the job that they were doing

in the data center, that
now gets turbocharged.
And also both...
We think easier but also different.
And so, you're talking to these folks.
They bring a lot of expertise.
They really do understand,
the networking needs of a workload
that you might run in the cloud.
But at the same time, you're bringing them
a bunch of new techniques

that actually means that
they're going to shift
how they spend their time.
And in those conversations,
I could see that there was
both excitement,

like, "Look at what we could
do in the cloud," right?
"We couldn't do that on premises."

As well as a little bit
of anxiety about this,
that difference of new skill set.
10 years later, we see that there was
a large scale embrace of these new skills.

A lot of the folks who
were previously spending

a lot of time on
undifferentiated heavy lifting,

of networking, data centers
are now spending time

operating a virtual
private cloud environment
in AWS with a lot more power.
So, this is going to be like that.

The mix of tasks in a
developer's day will be different
five years from now than they are today,
just like they are different today
than they were 10 years ago.

- You're right, you're
right. That sounds...

I mean, it reminds me of
when we went from assembly
and people were skeptical about compilers.
Like, "Oh, I can never trust a compiler
to do as good a job as I do."

And then once we moved from
C++ and C to Java and...

"Oh, it could never do
as good a job as I do."

And it turns out we have
more developers than ever,
and we still need some people
who know how to do those things.

Though not as many, and we're
just all way more productive

for not chasing NPEs and
things aren't anymore.
So, I think you're right.

I think it's going to be
just a shift in what we do.
- Yeah, fantastic.
So, you have a lot of peers of yours
from all around the world
watching our conversation today.

They're in a similar
situation that you are.
They have a staff of developers
who's both excited and anxious

about generative AI and
what that means for them.

Can you leave them with one
or two pieces of advice?
How can they navigate this successfully?

How can they help their staffs
navigate this successfully?

- I think the thing
that we've found helpful

and that actually even
our senior leadership

have reinforced now with us
is, get your hands dirty,
start using the tools,
don't prematurely optimize and say,

"Oh, this is not a good task
for gen AI or something."

Hit everything with a gen
AI stick for a little while.
Learn and see what's possible, embrace it.

Some of those aren't going to
go to production, that's fine.

Teams are learning, changing
their thinking models,
and so,

at this point, I think it's
really just start doing it.

- [Becky] Yeah.
- You know?
And no one's an expert.

Not too many people are
experts in this yet,

so we're all learning
together and just get started.

- Yeah, I mean, I would
absolutely echo that.
I would also say it's good to go in there
with sort of a realistic understanding

of the nature of new
technologies generally,
of which this is one.

And that means you're
going to have to listen

a little bit extra hard to
understand what's working,
where are we finding the sweet spots,

which are the wins that
we want to double down on,
which are the things where you're hearing
that it actually doesn't yet work well,
and maybe it's time to pause that

and take another look
at it because this is

rapidly evolving technology.
- That's right.

I think that's a really,
really critical point.
This is one of the biggest changes now is,
in the previous waves of technology,
if something didn't work,
maybe you'd wait 12 months, 18 months

and wait for the next version
of something to come out,
and then you could try again.

Now, it's three months,
two months, a few weeks.
So, it's important not to write things off
because they didn't work today.

The change could be
right around the corner
that makes it workable for you.
- Just make sure that folks
have the space to actually learn
these are legitimately new skills,

they're going to change the
mix of how we spend our days,
and make sure that they have the space
to skill up for modern development,
what will be modern development skills
in the next couple of years.
- Absolutely. Absolutely.

- Well, Tony, I wanted
to thank you so much

for spending time with us on
the Executive Insights podcast.

- Thanks for this opportunity.
It's been great being here.
- Thank you so much.
